reviews.review: "Another Simple Favor," the sequel I awaited with the kind of breathless anticipation usually reserved for a fresh episode of Dateline where the spouse definitely did it. It was a thrill to hear Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively were reprising their roles, presumably after their characters attended a masterclass in how to systematically unlearn the art of acting. One can only assume the rest of the returning cast got a group discount. The real masterstroke, however, seems to have been handing the screenwriting duties over to our new AI overlords. The resulting script is a glorious, pixelated vomit of what a machine thinks human audiences crave after binge-watching every derivative thriller ever made. It's a meticulously calculated, yet utterly soulless, retread that has all the organic charm of a chatbot trying to express genuine human emotion. "Insert witty banter here," the script probably read, "Ensure plot twist every 7.5 minutes for optimal audience engagement." If you were hoping for the dark, twisted fun of the original, prepare instead for a journey into the uncanny valley of filmmaking. Written by an AI that was fed nothing but rejected Lifetime movie scripts and the diary entries of an angsty teenager who just discovered what "plot twists" are. The twists are telegraphed with such aggressive obviousness, you'll feel less like a detective and more like you're patiently waiting for a toddler to find an Easter egg you placed directly in their line of sight. So, I'll be over here, basking in the comforting glow of Keith Morrison's narration, patiently waiting for a movie that doesn't feel like it was conceived in a server farm. This? This was less a simple favor and more a cinematic cry for help.

Blake Lively delivered a tour de force performance that captivated both audiences and critics alike, seamlessly blending emotional depth with effortless charisma. Her portrayal was lauded for its nuance and authenticity, earning widespread acclaim for elevating the film’s emotional core. Equally striking were her fashion choices—each ensemble a masterclass in style, curated with precision and flair. From high-fashion couture to bold, statement-making silhouettes, Lively’s wardrobe not only complemented her character’s arc but cemented her status as a modern-day style icon.

Another Simple Favor takes everything that works about the first film and tries to double down on it. Unfortunately this time, instead of resulting in a solid final product, this movie comes off as an overly elaborate mess that feels right at home on streaming. Ugh. I liked this first film and hoped they would do something interesting with this one, but it’s just your standard Paul Feig streaming film that feels like Adam Sandler’s Murder Mystery movies at times. For instance, Feig directs the picture without much of a feeling for Capri, a truly beautiful location to film at, but made it look as if it was shot on a studio backlot. The movie just feels cheap and lazy. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively lshare such playful chemistry (contrary to real life) that the laughs, zingers, and shady compliments flow effortlessly. Amidst the gorgeous Italian setting and lavish costumes, this overstuffed sequel still manages to entertain. But I have to admit, that third act really tried my patience. Far too many ridiculous twists with sluggish pacing. Too campy, too forced, not thrilling, just not great overall. Another Simple Favor essentially plays out the shift from art to “content” in real time… it’s painful to see.
One of the worst writing, acting and movie I’ve seen in years. How a high budget production and company didn’t realize this movie was going to be that bad.

(CASTELLANO) Otro pequeño favor llega con la difícil tarea de dar continuidad a una película que, sin ser revolucionaria, funcionaba por su frescura, estilo y las interpretaciones de Kendrick y Lively. Esta secuela, sin embargo, se queda a medio camino de todo. Intenta repetir fórmula, pero sin sorpresa. Hay giros, hay glamour, hay localizaciones europeas con postales de catálogo… pero falta algo fundamental: sentido. Hollywood lleva años obsesionado con rodar en Europa como sinónimo de sofisticación, pero aquí más bien parece una excusa vacacional para el equipo. Y eso se nota. Capri está preciosa, sí, pero ¿realmente ayuda a la historia? No. Si algo lastra esta entrega es precisamente la sensación constante de que todo es forzado, de que la chispa de la original se ha perdido y de que los personajes actúan más por compromiso que por convicción. Kendrick y Lively siguen siendo lo mejor, aunque se les nota algo contenidas. La trama, en cambio, se desinfla rápido, sin rumbo claro y con un final tan absurdo como innecesario. Y lo peor es que, aun durando menos de dos horas, se hace larga. Es como cuando una serie que adorabas se renueva una temporada más y, de pronto, todo se siente innecesario. En resumen: no es un desastre absoluto, pero sí un ejemplo más de que no todo lo que tiene éxito necesita una secuela. A veces es mejor dejar un buen recuerdo que arriesgarse a estropearlo. (ENGLISH) Another Simple Favor arrives with the difficult task of following up a film that, while not groundbreaking, worked thanks to its freshness, style, and the performances of Kendrick and Lively. This sequel, however, falls short on almost every front. It tries to repeat the formula but without any surprise. There are twists, there’s glamour, there are European locations that look like postcards... but what’s really missing is purpose. Hollywood has been obsessed for years with filming in Europe as a shortcut to sophistication, but here it just feels like an excuse for a team vacation. And it shows. Capri looks beautiful, sure, but does it add anything to the story? Not really. What weighs this sequel down is the constant sense that everything is forced, that the original spark is gone, and that the characters are moving more out of obligation than conviction. Kendrick and Lively remain the best part, although they feel a bit restrained. The plot, on the other hand, deflates quickly, directionless and with an ending that’s both absurd and unnecessary. Worst of all, even though it’s under two hours, it feels long. It’s like when a show you once loved gets renewed for one season too many—and suddenly, everything feels pointless. In short: it’s not a total disaster, but it’s yet another example that not every successful story needs a sequel. Sometimes it’s better to leave things on a high note than to risk ruining the memory.

Didn't the first one have a rather interesting premise of a crime thriller drama with an almost-comedic tone.. that felt like it lost the audience by the revelations and the underwritten third act? I'd call that consistency! And interesting to see a sequel at all. So! The script overall doesn't really deliver, the ending is not satisfying, and it just is a list of events that bring no character arcs or development or growth. Making the interesting people from the first a backdrop. And there's not even message or takeaway. The execution is also a series of too many little things that bring this down enough below acceptable or enjoyable. From bad pacing to a lack of tension. But putting it aside.. the acting is good, the camerawork decent, the locations gorgeous. And for once, the premise felt fresh and I didn't have a clue where it would take me! Just not enough to want to recommend this to anyone, want to watch it again, or give it a higher score. It was less than "okay".
As a tandem, the "Simple Favor" movies stand up pretty well on their own merits. The first one was generally well-liked, but the second one isn't the bomb that the numbers indicate.

"Another Simple Favor" is quite different from its suspense-twist driven predecessor, "A Simple Favor" - opting instead for a campier take, parodying the raunchy and ridiculous plot points this story has undertaken. And tbh, I was completely down for it. The first iteration was, in my opinion, too dreary and serious at times, leaving audiences slightly bored. However, this new update is able to highlight Anna Kendrick's sarcastic, laid back comedy to lead the tone of this film to great effect with similarly eclectic characters, such as Blake Lively's (aka Emily's) character, Lively plays the one minute your goofy AF bff to your quite possible maybe murder suspect, to a deliciously fun effect, alongside heightened returning characters in the love interest, Henry Golding, and new introductions, including Emily's hunky fiancé, slick mother-in-law, delirious birth mother and outspoken aunt to the fray. To note, the film can be incredibly insensitive, especially when there is a terrible mishandling of a R scene - without focusing on the gravity of the event at all - this storyline was added purely for a callback joke, which is downright disgusting and downplays real, distressing experiences. In addition, I feel like the Black sassy best friend one-note stereotype is incredibly old, and we need more dimensional POC characters. This has been said time and time again. This sequel is literally a fun murder mystery fully aware to its silly tropes, and we're here for it - best used for a digestable, quick watch.

The dynamic between the two lead actresses still works, especially in the first half of the movie, but... damn! What a mess of a plot in the second half! It's turning into such a stupid story that it ruins all the fun.

Loved the dynamic between the two main leads and loved how it made the whole plot come together without leaving any plot holes. Most of the the hate seems forced apart from what is going on in the blake lively case the movie is genuinely a fun movie watch.

"Another Simple Favor" has returned with a sequel featuring Blake Lively and Anna Kendrick, and while it may not have impressed the general audience, I have to say I found it hilariously entertaining. Sure, it may not be a masterpiece of comedy, but it certainly has enough creativity to continue the story of Emily and Stephanie. I thought the first film was a solid watch, especially with its intriguing twin twist. I’ll give a slight spoiler here for those who haven't seen it: the introduction of a triplet adds a fun layer to the plot, and I appreciated the unique direction they took. In my opinion, the sequel is far from bad. I genuinely enjoyed it from start to finish. Emily's character development into a new persona while retaining her quirky charm was delightful. Meanwhile, Stephanie’s growth, despite her often frustratingly naïve behavior, still hits the right notes. I'm definitely on board for a potential trilogy; the groundwork has been laid, and I would fully support it. It's a shame this installment went straight to streaming instead of hitting theaters, especially since the first film was a box office success. Nevertheless, I had a great time watching it and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it!

There were parts that were really very good, but then it kinda went a little flat. The repartee between Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively is what these movies is all about. It is sassy and funny. The first 1/3 to 1/2 of the movie had a whole lot of this and it really carried the movie. But then the characters kinda diverge from one another and the movie slowed down. The whodunit portion was OK but a little silly. Overall I liked it but it could have been better.

More than just a disappointment, this film was so bad it made me angry. The cynicism, the laziness on display here are an insult to film-making. Nothing makes sense, nor does it even try to. I had high hopes for this film after the camp delights of the original, but wow, what a shocker this is. Outrageous costumes and settings aren't enough, the script needs to make sense, to move us, to make us laugh or to feel suspense. This pile of crap just made my teeth ache and made me wonder how people like Allison Janney (dear god, nooooo!) can be so desperate for cash? for work? (surely not) that they lend their talent to such bilge! Next time Allison please treat yourself to some well earned time off and trust that the universe will provide. You only do yourself a disservice by lending your name to this sort of rubbish. Shame on everyone involved.

"Another Simple Favor" (2025) reunites Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively, promising more of the dark humor and twisty intrigue that made the first film a cult hit. However, this sequel ultimately falls flat, failing to recapture the engaging spark of its predecessor and delivering a narrative that struggles to hold the viewer's attention. While the film retains the stylish visuals, sharp fashion, and the undeniable chemistry between Kendrick and Lively, these elements aren't enough to compensate for a plot that feels convoluted and increasingly absurd. The initial intrigue quickly dissipates as the story spirals into outlandish scenarios that lack the grounded wit and surprising twists of the original. The attempts at dark comedy often feel forced, and the mystery at the heart of the narrative fails to generate genuine suspense. The characters, while still portrayed with a certain flair by the lead actresses, become entangled in increasingly unbelievable situations, making it difficult to remain invested in their fates. The pacing of the film contributes to the lack of engagement. Scenes often feel drawn out, and the numerous plot twists, rather than adding excitement, become tiresome and detract from any sense of realism or believability. The film struggles to maintain a consistent tone, further hindering the viewer's ability to connect with the story. Ultimately, "Another Simple Favor" prioritizes style and shock value over a compelling and engaging narrative. While the return of Kendrick and Lively offers some initial appeal, the film's convoluted plot and lack of genuine intrigue make it a disappointing sequel that fails to capture the magic of the first "simple favor."

Another Simple Favor wants to have its cocktail and spike it too. A follow-up to the fizzy 2018 original, this sequel tries to recapture that mix of glossy noir and PTA mom chaos—but somewhere along the way, the martini got watered down. Anna Kendrick returns as Stephanie, still neurotic and over-eager, and Blake Lively slinks back into frame like she never left. Their chemistry remains the film’s biggest asset—whip-smart, deliciously off-kilter, and peppered with just enough menace. But while their dynamic once felt fresh, it now plays like fan service on autopilot. The plot? Think Clue, if every card said “twist.” It’s all double-crosses and fake deaths and improbable alliances, but the stakes feel lower this time, like the film is more interested in looking clever than being clever. Director Paul Feig keeps things moving with his signature shine, but the script leans harder into camp than intrigue, and not always in a good way. To be fair, it’s never boring. There are moments of sharp humor, outfits to kill for, and the occasional flash of that first film’s biting tone. But there’s also a nagging sense that everyone’s winking a little too hard at the camera, like they're in on a joke that’s no longer quite as funny. Final verdict: Another Simple Favor is a flirty little con game that looks great on the outside but doesn’t land its final trick. Stylish? Sure. But memorable? Not so much.

Review: Another Simple Favor (2025) The only thing simple about this sequel is how easily it squanders everything that worked the first time. A particular kind of sequel thinks being “shocking” is the same as being clever. Another Simple Favor, the follow-up to 2018’s sleek and stylish dark comedy, falls headfirst into that trap and keeps tumbling with glee. What was once a clever, twisted, fashion-forward mystery now plays like a parody of itself, and not in a good way. This time, the story trades suburban scandal for sunny Capri, Italy. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively return. The script gives them little to work with beyond absurd plot turns and hollow provocations. It all feels like the writers are throwing darts at a board labeled “shocking,” “sexy,” and “sinister,” hoping something lands. Nothing does. Yes, it’s campy. Yes, it’s over the top. But even campy needs structure and even outrageous twists need emotional or narrative context. Another Simple Favor confuses escalation with storytelling. There’s one scene, unfortunately, burned into my memory that aims to be edgy and daring but instead comes off as lazy, gross, and utterly unearned. I’m no prude, but provocation without purpose is just a cheap trick. By the time we reach the final act, any remnants of character integrity or tonal coherence have been tossed out with yesterday’s Aperol spritz. And yet, somehow, the film dares to believe it’s pulled off something brilliant. ***SPOILER*** Emily walks away once again, untouched, smirking like the film just won a game none of us agreed to play. Ultimately, Another Simple Favor isn’t fun, clever, or even trashy in an enjoyable way. It’s a beautiful mess without the beauty and a thriller that forgets to thrill. If you loved the first film, protect that memory. This sequel is a complete waste of time. Rating: 1.5 out of 5 martinis. Recommendation: Skip it. Or rewatch the original and pretend this one never happened.

I was genuinely excited to see the sequel to A Simple Favor. The first film left such a strong impression on me—not only because of its clever storytelling but also thanks to the standout performances by Blake Lively and Anna Kendrick, whose chemistry and charisma truly elevated the movie. Naturally, I had high expectations for this follow-up, and I must say, it managed to surprise me right from the opening scene. Although the plot of the sequel is relatively straightforward and perhaps less intricate than the first, it doesn’t really matter. The film’s true strength lies in its undeniable charm—beautiful cinematography that captures every scene with style and flair, paired with witty, often hilarious dialogue that keeps the audience engaged. It’s a film that doesn’t take itself too seriously, and that lightness is part of its appeal. Blake and Anna once again deliver outstanding performances, their chemistry as compelling as ever. Watching them together feels effortless, and their playful banter adds a layer of fun that makes the movie all the more enjoyable. Like the first film, this sequel is peppered with twists and turns—some predictable, others more surprising—that keep the narrative lively and dynamic. Despite a few bizarre moments—such as the scene where Blake's character kisses herself—the overall tone remains entertaining and occasionally hilarious. While the plot may seem shallow on the surface, I found myself genuinely enjoying the direction it took. The story explores new facets of these characters, pushing their boundaries and revealing unexpected sides of them. That said, I did leave the film feeling a bit underwhelmed by the ending. It wrapped up some storylines but left others feeling unresolved—particularly regarding Dante’s fate, which I suspect might not be as clear-cut as it appeared. I’m curious whether the filmmakers intend to revisit this universe in a third installment, especially given the subtle hints dropped at the conclusion. I certainly hope they do, because there’s still so much more to explore with these characters. In summary, despite some flaws and a somewhat open-ended finale, this sequel manages to be a thoroughly enjoyable watch. It’s a perfect blend of style, wit, and chemistry, with enough twists to keep viewers intrigued. While I expected a bit more closure, I’m optimistic about what the future holds for these characters—and I’m definitely eager to see where the story goes next.

This movie was however, redeemed by Anna Kendrick's and Blake Lively's chemistry that screams 'perfection'. These two brought the thunder for the sequel, with their characters leaving the past behind to face the cruel future that awaits them, Blake and Anna made a solid stand and redeemed this movie from total damnation. The humor shall not go unnoticed......

Just when you thought your summer couldn't get steamier, Another Simple Favor crashes in like a martini-fueled mystery in heels. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively reunite with all the snappy, sinister charm of the original — only this time they’ve upgraded to the impossibly chic coastlines of Capri, Italy. (Yes, Capri. Yes, I gasped too.) Blake Lively? Please. She’s not just acting — she’s serving runway realness in every frame. If the Oscar voters don't make a separate category for “Best Use of Silk, Sunglasses, and Suspicion,” we riot. Enter Michele Morrone and Henry Golding, turning up the heat and the tension in this deliciously twisted Mediterranean Noir. Think White Lotus meets Gone Girl, with just enough comedy to make you feel safe… right before it doesn’t. Director Paul Feig keeps things sharp, stylish, and just unhinged enough to make you question everyone’s motives — including your own. And major kudos to producer Laura Fischer for letting the characters and the wardrobe breathe. And let’s not pretend: there’s a shower "sex" scene that deserves its own end credits. You’ll know it when it hits -- and now I need some cake. Thrills. Laughs. Limoncello. And looks that kill. Another Simple Favor is everything you didn’t know you needed this season — and probably more than you deserve.

However, she plays this role beautifully in the first film and this one (whether she's playing herself or not,, or a version she wants to be, it's up for debate) but she does it so well. This film is a cross between "What happened to baby Jane" mixed with a little of Agatha Christie) . It's really different than the first film which was more dark, where this takes a fun CAMPY take on what happened afterwards. And that is the warning. It's for the girls, the gays and the they's. Blake Lively, had only done two movies I've liked her in: A Simple Favor and A Another Simple Favor. I can detach the person from the character and give praise where praise is due. I am not much on fashion when it comes to movies, didn't know I cared that much, but Blake Lively's characters outfits were breathtaking. I never care about that stuff but it was impressive here. And I hate to say it but I love her in this role. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively together are like Velma Kelly and Roxy Hart. They may hate each other off screen, but their dynamic onscreen is undeniable. They play off each other so well. SO THIS IS A WARNING, this movie is CAMP. It's fun, ridiculous, but well crafted. The scenery and costumes are beyond incredible and they are so good together. I loved it. It was so like much What ever happened to Baby Jane kind of dark humor but more self aware to it's absurdness. The writing, which had been clever and engaging in the first third, quickly devolved into a convoluted mess. The plot turned silly and the characters followed suit. Lots of cringeworthy moments and laughable dialogue. The last two-thirds of the movie were hard to watch. The talented cast was let down by subpar writing and editing. If you're a fan of the original, you might want to approach this sequel with caution.

Stephanie travels to the picturesque island of Capri to be Emily's maid of honor — but what starts as a lavish wedding spirals into a tangled web of secrets, mafia feuds, and dark humor. Directed with a playful, irreverent tone, Another Simple Favor mixes crime, comedy, and melodrama against stunning Italian backdrops. The film leans heavily on surprise twists, sometimes sacrificing coherence for shock value. Blake Lively and Anna Kendrick remain magnetic together, carrying the story even when it stretches too thin. Visually, the movie dazzles — with lush cinematography and stylish set design — but narratively, it lacks the psychological depth that made the original 2018 film so compelling. Instead, it opts for surface-level satire of wealth and crime, offering a fun yet ultimately less resonant sequel. A colorful, entertaining ride for fans of dark comedy, though it never fully recaptures the sharpness of its predecessor.

A sequel to 2018's A SIMPLE FAVOR and director Paul Feig's first sequel doesn't quite capture the magic of its predecessor but it's still a worthy followup. Whereas the original film is based upon a novel of the same name, ANOTHER SIMPLE FAVOR is an original story continuing the hostile relationship between mothers and besties/former besties Stephanie Smothers (Anna Kendrick) and Emily Nelson (Blake Lively). The story follows Stephanie being invited to Emily's wedding in Capri to serve as Emily's maid of honor, which is rather curious judging from the way these characters left each other in the first film. During the wedding events on the Italian island, one of the wedding guests is murdered in their hotel room and Emily must once again uncover who's behind it before she herself could be the next target. Much like another recently released film THE ACCOUNTANT 2, I didn't hear anyone clamoring for a return to this property. And to be completely transparent, I had my reservations about it for 2 reasons: I rather enjoyed the original film and didn't think a sequel would deliver the same quality. In addition Amazon Prime doesn't put out quality products in my humble opinion. So imagine my surprise at how much I enjoyed this film. Stephanie's character has grown since the last time we saw her. She's not the pushover mom she once was, has found her career in solving crimes, and even writes a book about her experience in the first film. Lively is once again the powerhouse character she was the first time around: foul-mouthed, completely unapologetic with a great sense of style. Seriously, whoever's designing this character for both films is most certainly earning their keep. However, I will say the story, while interesting, isn't as tight, smart, or razor thin during its sophomore session. Although there are plenty of humorous one-liners to go around alongside plenty of colorful language. And while I'm not sure there's room here for a trilogy, but if they did proceed with a third story, I'd watch with more anticipation than I did this entry.

Read on for an unbiased and objective review of this film based solely on the film itself. I had high expectations for Another Simple Favour given its director Paul Feig (Spy, Bridesmaids) and two lead actresses Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively. Initially, I felt the original movie sat well as a standalone feature, not requiring a follow-up. Therefore, I was surprised at Another's announcement recently. I have decided to give the film a 2 & a half star rating as whilst it was watchable, I began to lose interest, I enjoyed the first half which built to somewhat of an anti-climax in the latter half, spiralling into utter insanity devoid of realism and interesting "twists". In my personal opinion, I feel this movie was better aesthetically, in terms of the setting and the camerawork which was stunning, showcasing the beautiful scenery of Italy. However, on the contrary, this film has more big name stars compared to A Simple Favour, although, it begs to ask the question why? It does not add any substance or contribution to the sequel. That being said, I am a huge fan of new addition Allison Janney and numerous other cast members. Having said that, the writing is poor and the story seems somewhat rushed. *Pay close attention, all creators to this paragraph* Writing is the foundation of any good story and no amount of star-studded cast announcements, marketing and/or perfected imagery will salvage that. It is transparent to fans when a story lacks quality. It is a shame as I wish the film was better and I wanted it to be just that. My biggest surprise was that the cast members are such accredited artists of whom are outstanding in previous work in an individual capacity which I may list below. Anna Kendrick (Pitch Perfect) Blake Lively (Gossip Girl) Henry Golding (Crazy Rich Asians) Elizabeth Perkins (Miracle on 34th Street) Allison Janney (I, Tonya) Alex Newell (Zoey's Extraordinary Playlist) In summary, I watched the film from start to finish. I enjoyed the first half, it began to become boring in the second half. I probably would not revisit this film again as other movies have proved much better. However, one last favour was teased at the end? If Another Simple Favour was excellent, a third would be unnecessary, however, a third may lessen the comparisons between the original and its sequel. Who knows? Paul Feig did create Bridesmaids, which remains one of the best comedy films of all time.

"Another Simple Favor is the kind of twisty, stylish sequel that actually earns its second act. Blake Lively returns as effortlessly cool and chaotic as ever, while Anna Kendrick’s charm and comedic timing once again ground the madness in just enough reality. The fashion? Iconic. The plot? Delightfully unhinged. It’s part thriller, part satire, and 100% fun. If you loved the first film’s blend of mystery and dark humor, this follow-up doesn’t just deliver — it doubles down. Count me in for another favor... or three."

It’s rare these days to find a film that truly embraces comedy as a craft without taking itself too seriously and forgetting to have some fun! Like the perfect martini, Another Simple Favor has the right amount of witty bite balanced by a wash of pleasing aesthetic taste. It takes a bitter wedge of lemony revenge and twists it into hints of mystery in every scene. Its cast of characters are familiar from the first film but refreshed with the icy touch of their distrust of one another without ever watering down the inner fire of a well-timed sip. This sequel hit like that perfect second cocktail on a sunny vacation day!

Loved this movie as much as the first one. However, I’m frustrated by the number of low ratings that seem to be based on external controversies rather than the film itself. The situation involving Blake Lively is complex and sensitive, and it’s disappointing to see people dismissing her work entirely based on assumptions. Reviews should focus on the movie and the performances, not personal opinions about an actor’s private life. We should be mindful of how we discuss situations where a woman has spoken out, as public judgment can become another form of harm.

If Another Simple Favor were a cocktail, it’d be a martini with a cyanide twist—dangerously stylish, unexpectedly sharp, and served with a wink. It’s less “whodunnit” and more “who didn’t?” The dry humor, the twists, the perfectly timed eye-roll moments—it all just works. Big shoutout to Paul Feig for making mystery feel like a high-fashion comedy of errors, and to Laura Fischer for bringing another deliciously chaotic story to life!

7 years have passed since director Paul Feig brought his dark comedy thriller Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively also return to reprise their roles as dyer frenemies Stephanie and Emily Stephanie has made a successful career being an author of her past encounters with Emily, the fashion public relations woman who played a deadly game of cat and mouse conning her husband out of life insurance and finding out she murdered her parents and twin sister Emily was sentenced to prison but she has gotten out getting engaged to a wealthy European man Dante in Capri, Italy New cast members include Alison Janney and Elizabeth Perkins attending the wedding as Emily’s relatives Emily’s ex husband Julien and her son are here too much to their reluctance But given their history Stephanie is unsure she can trust Emily ever again especially when a new murder happens creating a puzzle of whodunnit It’s an international adventure murder mystery this time around It has a feeling of Agatha Christie too making everyone a top suspect Lively still perfectly encapsulates Emily being unpredictable, unhinged, and unwilling to give up Kendrick as Stephanie is much more open, less apologetic, stern, and independent Yet she still carries around guilt for all the dead men in her life They have that repitoire that makes it crackle digging into each other with claws I didn’t expect a lot of Freudian stuff going on either The film still has much of the dark, snarky humor as well as the sharp dialogue Plenty of sharp casting as far as the supporting characters and the Italian scenery is quite beautiful to look at I’ll admit too the plot keeps building on upon itself taking all kinds of unexpected turns People do all kinds of things for money, power, family, and love I have to say this follow up is deliciously wicked and even more appealing than the original film being funny and sexy at the same time Even the costumes are excellent to behold matching the exotic location’s sleek nature Yes some of the plot twists can be absurd straining logic yet the sizzling chemistry of the two leading ladies is still what holds it together It’s hard to resist because you cannot deny it’s visually lush appeal as well as the actresses So whatever you think about Lively’s current situation in the headlines today she still brings her A-game here next to Kendrick being a combination of murder, Italian tourism, and fashion in another black comedy

Sequel to the 2018 film “A Simple Favor”, “Another Simple Favor” is a mind-blowing experience. It's like being on a roller coaster: a continuous up and down without knowing which direction the story will take. Between a black comedy and a thriller, “Another Simple Favor” is a delirious and glossy sequel, between criminal families, a wedding and mysteries to solve. Blake Lively and Anna Kendrick were born for these roles. Just like in the first movie, they give us two brilliant performances and they share a great chemistry, which for the viewer is always a pleasure to see. To conclude, wonderful locations, plot twists, fast pace, intrigue, mystery and, as in the first chapter, a pinch of comedy, make this sequel irresistible. Highly recommended! It's been a long time since I had this much fun watching a movie. PS. Rewatching the first film (or watching it if you've never done it) is highly recommended.

Wedding Cinema for the Feminine Sleuth In just a few days, this movie will be released on Prime Video, and I am genuinely grateful to have had the opportunity to experience it in Dolby at Regal Cinemas. Some pictures are photographed in a way that the silver screen neither benefits nor hinders, but this isn’t one of those films. Bathed in blues and pastels, the cinematography was like a floral tapestry of Mediterranean colors, dancing around the characters in wides and ariels. While it was clear that meticulous thought went into each shot, it never felt controlled. The locations felt real, as if I watched it from a bedroom window in Italy with my own eyes. The frame never felt small, but also never too large. Capturing their moments like God’s canvas, each splash of light like another shade of flower. Whodunits are notoriously rocky, destructive little stories. Built around suspense and thrill, every beat always leading to a crescendo of turmoil. While a mystery is typically born from an unsuspected death, its consequences are rarely circumstantial. This is the standard for the genre, and yet, none of these traits can be used to explain “Another Simple Favor”. And that’s where it shines. When I took my seat, I was surprised by the number of conversations I heard between other audience members. A packed theater, barely a seat open, and over and over I kept hearing the same thing, “I didn’t know this was a sequel.” Being a fan of the first one, that worried me. Was this the audience to see this flick with? Are they going to be bored? Will they laugh? Will they tremor? Will they understand it or judge it for not knowing how to understand it? I am pleased to say that none of my anxious thoughts came to fruition. “Another Simple Favor” played like a standalone film, never force feeding you exposition for the sake of it. I walked out of the theater hearing many people saying they were going to go home and watch the first one, treating “A Simple Favor” more like a prequel. And that’s because it never pandered to the audience. This movie doesn’t just try to speak to its demographic; it converses with it fluently, always with a knowing wink and a confident nod. It knew what it was before the projector turned on, and because of that, we did too. While I had initially wondered how a sequel could be born from the first picture, I accepted it wholeheartedly by the time the inciting incident occurred—something I had rarely experienced beforehand. With banter shifting between characters at a Gilmore-esque speed, it was done more charmingly than you would expect. It never shied away from its vulgar sharpness that made the first movie so much fun to watch. Each dig felt naturally pointed. Never artificial and planted. While the tone frequently dripped with brilliant sarcasm and extreme wit, the characters also fumbled with digs at one another, as if their wit had dried up. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively play off of one another like a stage play on its fifteenth performance, dueling with each another as if their tongues were swords. The comedy never lingers awkwardly between them—it lands clean, then cuts, triggering laughter throughout the room whenever prompted. It always held its tongue firmly pressed to the cheek. Part of me craved a crack in its smile—a moment where the mask slips. But then again, maybe that’s the brilliance. It never lets the wine spill. Once again, though, that wasn’t a detriment as this comes back to its remarkable feat of self-awareness. What Paul Feig and MGM created was a wedding film for true-crime enthusiasts, armchair detectives, and wine moms with a twisted sense of humor. It's a mystery that plays beat for beat like a razor-sharp paperback in the window of your favorite bookstore, with a cover doused in floral and blood stains. This movie may not be for everyone, but for those it’s for, you’ll be pressed to find one that knows you this well.
